talk.start.para: âI want to take this opportunity to table a report that details activities undertaken by me as parliamentary adviser to the Australian delegation to the 52nd General Assembly of the United Nations.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI would like to start by thanking the citizens of Australia for giving me this quite unique opportunity to be part of the delegation at the United Nations last year. It is not an opportunity that comes to all parliamentarians. Only two parliamentarians each year have this very special opportunity. It was quite unique and it was a privilege to have been able to participate in the work of the Australian mission in New York and to have been brought into the work of the United Nations from the end of September-October to December.

speech.para: I want to detail some of the recommendations that I have made as a result of my experience at the United Nations. My report covers recommendations; the role of a parliamentary adviser; the key issues of the 52nd General Assembly, which for me were UN reform, Iraq, the third committee and the sixth committee; conferences and meetings; Australia's human rights policy; women's rights; and follow-up projects for 1998. In attending so many sessions and in observing the work of the mission, I found that it was possible, when I came back, to review and assess those areas where I thought in future we could build on Senator Patterson's and my experience and indeed on the experience of those members of parliament who have been attending the General Assembly since the mid-1960s.

First of all, it is a practice that should continue. It is a wonderful opportunity for this parliament to be kept in touch with the work of the United Nations. But there are areas where we could perhaps update and change some of the practices that would better benefit and assist Australia in terms of how we are perceived within the United Nations itself. I would like to read my recommendations, or as many of them as I can with this opportunity. First of all, in relation to the role of parliamentary advisers to the Australian mission to the United Nations, I state:

The role of parliamentary advisers needs to be more clearly defined to maximise personal professional development, the opportunity to provide practical support to the Australian Mission and an ongoing commitment to the work of the United Nations.
I think that ongoing commitment is very important. I also state:

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade should consider developing a set of guidelines, including practical administrative arrangements, to assist parliamentary advisers prepare for this transfer of duty.

The issue of electorate staff being able to travel at private expense to be involved in the work of the delegation should be fully considered and officially clarified to assist the work of future parliamentary advisers.

When you are participating in this delegation, you have to do both your work from Australia and your work from the United Nations. I did not have any staff with me. But I commend my colleague Senator Patterson, who made special arrangements and assisted with the funding of electorate staff. I think that is highly commendable. It did enable her, I am sure, to better keep across some of her responsibilities than in my case, where I always seemed to be rushing to complete work that had to be done to send back to Australia. In relation to the Australian mission to the United Nationsâas you would understand, Madam President, this is a perennial recommendationâI state:
The staffing and resource levels of the Australian Mission should be increased to maximise the participation of Australia in all areas of the United Nations.

I commend the role of the ambassador, our first woman ambassador, Penny Wensley, who is absolutely dedicated. She has so much energy that it is very hard to keep up with her in all that she does at the United Nationsânot just with being involved in committees and the General Assembly, but also in discussing issues with all her colleagues. But there were times when I wished she had more resources, including staffing, to keep that momentum going. It is always a difficulty whenever resources are mentioned. All governments have good reasons for not funding at certain levels. But I do think it is an issue that should always be being reviewed. The United Nations is where Australia is showcasing its view of the world in so many areas, and we need the resources and the staffing to do that for maximum benefit.
I have also raised an issue that I think is perhaps the only controversial issue in my recommendations, and I want to explain it. I have said:

There could be greater appreciation of the professionalism of overseas-based Australian officers involved in day-to-day negotiations, thus limiting some of the protracted New York-Canberra-New York communication, which can be both inefficient and out of step with the climate of opinion within the United Nations.

I want to emphasise that I am not referring to the foreign minister here, because obviously the foreign minister has the absolute right, indeed responsibility, to be in touch on a daily basis. But at the bureaucratic level I did get the impression at times that there was a little too much dabbling from Canberra. Where we were in New York the staff were fully across the issues, fully across the nuances of the debate, and it was very time consuming to have phone calls, faxes and e-mails disrupting the flow of debate and negotiations. I am not a professional in terms of the officer level, but I did feel that we need to ensure that there is a good briefâwhich there isâof the broad issues and the general line of government policy and then leave it to the professionals and of course the minister's office.
In the few minutes remaining I want to run through the last itemâthough there are a few more recommendations: Australia's role at the United Nations. I think we need to develop:
. . . a forward plan of those priority areas where the Australian Government can take a leadership role and offer relevant expertise.

I think that we could be doing more in that area. I think priority should be given to developing a register of suitable candidates for nomination to be available for appointment to various United Nations committees, particularly giving attention to women and men from a variety of professional backgrounds with community based experience. Finally:

The Australian Government should develop a comprehensive strategy to raise the profile of Australia within the United Nations building to include art exhibitions, a food and wine festival, cultural performances, Australian craft availabilityâ
in the gift shop, for instance, there was nothing from Australiaâ
. . . Such a strategy should ideally culminate in special 1999 events to preview Australia prior to the Olympic Games.

In conclusion, could I again praise Ambassador Penny Wensley and her staff for the role they fulfil. It was a unique opportunity. Senator Patterson and I are very grateful to have been the lucky ones selected on this occasion.

talk.start.para: âI have in the past stood in this place and been critical of an adversary of mine, one Mr Richard Egan from Western Australia. That criticism arose because of the position he adopted on illegal entrants to this country, boat people in particularâpeople who had been confined in perhaps Port Hedland and other places. We have had our differences on that particular subject matter over a number of years.

speech.para: Today, however, I have to get up and thank Mr Egan because of his actions and those of the people that he represents which were reported on pages 4 and 5 of yesterday's West Australian under the headline `Extremists cost us votes: pro-life MPs'. To explain that headline one has to go to the article under the headline `Abortion on demand' in today's West Australian. It talks about the Western Australian parliament yesterday and the previous day passing bills in both housesâlegislation which will give Western Australia, as is reported in the newspaper:
. . . the nation's most liberal abortion lawsâgiving women access to abortion on demandâafter two historic votes in State Parliament yesterday.
After sitting all night, the Legislative Council voted 22 to 11 about 5.30am to repeal the criminal law on abortion.

About 10.35am, after an exhausting debate in a sitting lasting nearly 24 hours, the Legislative Assembly voted 31 to 19 to pass the Government-sponsored abortion reform Bill to make abortion legal when a woman gives informed consent.

For many years I have been a supporter of a woman's right to choose. My name appeared in an advertisement in Tuesday's West Australian supporting that position. I was not hiding behind any bushel, and I do believe, although I have not checkedâthe chair of the Senators' Interests Committee will probably be able to check this for meâthat I have declared I am a member of an organisation that calls for abortion to be freely available to women who want it. Thanks to the antics of Mr Egan and his organisation, women in Western Australia should now be able to control their own bodies and their own lives in future.

It has been an exhausting debate for my parliamentary colleagues in the west. As the newspaper says, the debate raged in both houses simultaneously. This debate has gone on at a very intense pitch and paceâperhaps as intense as the euthanasia debate which we were involved in in this place last year. The hours that people have put in have been extremely long. The list of who voted for what in the votes are displayed on the front page, and it is rather surprising to see where the support for the right to choose came from.

The heartening thing about the overall result, irrespective of whatever moral positions individuals take on this issueâI know there are divergent viewsâis reflected in the headline of the editorial in today's newspaper which states, `MPs' vote reflects majority will'. It is a real bonus to the electorate of Western Australia that their elected parliamen tarians will take decisions that cross party boundaries and reflect the will of the people.

It has been indicated in public opinion polls that some 80 per cent of the population of Western Australia support either or both, or a mixture, of the bills that are going through the Western Australian parliament. If that is the case, it is not truly reflective of the vote in the parliament, but it is a darned sight more reflective than the vote in this place on the euthanasia bill, which we debated last year and which was carried. We in this chamber last year did not choose to reflect the will of the people on that issue.

Before leaving this issue, I want to say a few words about the antics of Mr Egan. I agree with him on one point: his criticism of the former Governor-Generalâalthough I do not necessarily share the views and criticisms on that particular issue. It just goes to show that, no matter how different you are, you can always be somewhat the same.

Some of Mr Egan's supporters call him an Ayatollah, fanatic or zealot. Perhaps nowâalthough I have not done so in the pastâI will seek to join them. Truly, some of the antics that these people got up to on this occasion have to be condemned. I am surprised that Archbishop Hickey, the Archbishop of Perth, has not come out and distanced himself from Mr Egan. I had expected Barry Hickey to distance himself after seeing Mr Egan following a group of women through the streets of Perth and abusing them in such a manner that it could have been seen to be physical abuse, not just verbal. Unfortunately, Archbishop Hickey did not do that. His Grace also joined one of the main speakers in the pro-life rally in Perth on Tuesday of last week.

That reflects poorly on the archbishop. These people had used stolen information about a group of 24 women who had had abortions and they publicised that information. That has been universally condemned. It is alleged that even people who supported the pro-life cause in the state parliament have been influenced by antics such as that. It may have influenced their vote. If so, I am very pleased that that is the case; Mr Egan and his group have served society well by their extremism because they may have given Western Australia the most liberal abortion laws in the country.

I will mention some of the other things that the group has done apart from the files that they released. On Tuesdayâthe same time as the advert I spoke of earlierâthey published their own front-page advertisement to promote their cause. That advertisement, which I deliberately have not taken a copy of to show to the chamber, included a photograph of the Premier of Western Australia, the Premier's wife and their child. They put that photograph in the newspaper without the permission of the Premier, his wife or his child.

We have some debates in this place and in the other place about family members of politicians, but I suggest that this is one of the instances where people really do have to look at the ethics of the causes that they promote. I doubt very much that they, or indeed anybody seeking to influence Mr Court, will seek to use his and his family's photograph in this way in the future. We know from statements that Mr Court has made to the newspapers that he, his family and his wife were very upset about the manner in which they used it.

The other thing that the group did, which again featured by way of an article on the front page of the West Australian newspaper, was supposedly show bloodied tools and gloves which were alleged to have been used in abortions. Again, tactics such as this turned off more people than they switched on to this issue. I do not have a problem with honest debate on things, as was proved in the euthanasia debate, which was quite divisive. I think I represented the majority view in the community. Unfortunately, the parliament, the Senate more properly, did not think the same way. But I do not think that any side of the parliament got down to the graceful and disgusting tactics that Mr Egan and his ilk got down to on this. If they are hurting because of the articles on the front page of the West Australian newspaper today, so be it. I am actually quite pleased that that be the case.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs: Questions on Notice

talk.start.para: âEarlier this week I gave notice of a motion in the Senate concerning the failure of the government in regard to its responses to the Senate's Employment, Education and Training Committeeânamely, the failure to respond to questions on notice and the failure to respond to committee reports, committee reports for which I note that, in the normal scheme of things, one could reasonably expect responses within a three-month period. There are three committee reports: Childhood matters: report on the inquiry into early childhood education , which was presented in July 1996; Beyond Cinderella , presented in April 1997; and Not a level playing field , presented in June 1997. I also drew attention to the fact that some 154 questions on notice will have remained unanswered at the appointed day for the return of questions to estimates.

speech.para: I would like to draw to the Senate's attention this evening that, as of 12.30 p.m. today, some 41 questions still remain unanswered. It strikes me that this is a disappointing response from a department. It strikes me that this reflects a deeper problem within the department. It strikes me that this reflects a deeper problem within government; that is, the failure of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, who has direct responsibility to this chamber for this portfolio. It reflects however a deeper problem that occurs as a result of this government's approach to education, and I have put the view in previous contributions to the chamber that this government is running down the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs to the point from where it was once a great department of state to its being a shadow of its former self.

The situation is that some two years ago the department had some 16,000 employees, but I understand from responses to answers given to me by the secretary, and confirmed in one of the answers that was received, that the department levels in the coming financial year will be down to 2,500. So that is from 16,000 to 2,500 in a little over two years: a dramatic decline, I would have thought, in anyone's language.

On top of that, we have a situation where the department is relying increasingly upon consultancies and what I regard are euphemistically termed service contractors. This difficulty is further reflected in the fact that the department cannot answer questions in the absolute, in the cases that I have mentioned, and, where they do, it is all too often the case that answers are given inaccurately. On simple propositions, for example, you ask a question of the department officials, `Give the figures in real terms,' and they give the answer back to you in out-turn prices. Simple propositions like that are of profound political importance in terms of the measurement of budgetary figures, and this is one example that occurred. But we have a much broader problem as a result of what I see as the gutting of the department itself. The secretary of the department, Mr Sedgwick, on 25 March circulated to all staff a minute entitled `DEETYA Resourcing'. It said:
When launching the Corporate Plan in December, I noted that

"The Department will always find ourselves needing to change, refocus, re-engineer and respond to [a] rapidly changing world. We will, therefore, continually look at what we are doing and how we do it. And it will lead to changes from time to time.

He goes on to point out that the government has provided resourcing that was `"zero based" to reflect the scale of operation required' once the various networks and other functions have closed. He says:
The time has now come for us to make some adjustments to our operation to reflect our ongoing resourcing and priorities.
He indicates about the department:
. . . will employ a little over 2,500 staff in 1998-99. This will require us to release or redeploy approximately 150 people from our current National Office payroll.
He says:
I have asked Division Heads to give me preliminary plans on how their Divisions can reach the numbers of positions available and allocated to them in line with our corporate priorities.
And so it goes. He indicates that:

The particular process to be followed in giving effect to the necessary reprioritisation of our activities will be determined at local level, in consultation with those affected. As usual, there is a range of options available. Depending on the circumstances, this means some temporary positions will cease, some vacancies will not be filled and some staff will be transferred to other functions.
He goes on:
Our aim, however, is to reach decisions on the way forward as quickly as possible so as to minimise uncertainty and dislocation.

Quite clearly this is desperately needed in this department. It is needed not just for the employees who have to face these very difficult decisions in terms of their personal futures, but it is desperately needed in terms of the people that this department serves: the five million students, the hundreds of thousands of unemployed persons, the various employer bodies, the various TAFE colleges and the various educational institutions of this country.

I put it to the Senate that this department is not able to fulfil its core functions adequately with this level of resourcing. It strikes me that this is a very serious problem which is reflected in the fact that this parliament can no longer get the service that it has a right to expect from a department on very simple measures like the answering of questions. It corresponds to a government attitude whereby it cannot respond adequately to committee reports.

But there is a further difficulty in the way in which this government approaches education. The minister earlier this week introduced to the parliament on a non-controversial basis a bill which highlighted matters relating to the indigenous education initiatives. The minister's claim in a press release that he is making per capita funding, under the target outcomes project for indigenous students, available to all students, not just those in larger schools, clearly implies that this was a matter of his own initiative.

The fact is that the government was forced into this position by the opposition. These were points I clearly made in the debate on this bill this week. Without the ALP's pressure, the government would not have even used the powers provided to it by its own legislation to provide the funding to indigenous students. It would have denied around 1,000 Aboriginal children access to funding which was payable under existing legislation. It was the opposition that forced the government to take this position.

What we see in the minister's press release is a different proposition being advanced. We do not mind that the bill is called non-controversial; we do not mind the minister now turning around and taking the credit. But we do believe that it is a very cheap trick for this government to seek to milk cheap publicity from what is a very serious issue and from the solution which was found as a result of the political process.

This is a press release worthy of Dr Kemp. I would have thought that Senator Ellison was a better minister than that. I would have thought that he would not have to rely on the Dr Goebbels techniques that we have seen demonstrated all too often by Dr Kemp.

Dr Kemp indicated this week that there would be no cuts to education funding this year and that somehow or other more places were being provided by this government than they were under the previous government, implying that there had been no reductions. The minister's higher education budget statement, for instance, says:
A further reduction of 3 per cent (a cumulative total of 4 per cent) on funding previously announced for 1998 will be a major efficiency dividend sought from this sector.

We notice from the statements in the estimates that there was a cumulative effect of 21,000 fewer places being provided under this government than previously would have been provided under Labor. This situation is quite contrary to the position that is being advanced by the government. (Time expired)

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI wish to speak about what I regard as the saddest day in the history of the Western Australian parliament. I refer to the vote allowing abortion on demand in Western Australia. It will be regarded as the saddest day in Western Australia's history because abortion is the deliberate killing of an unborn child. Regretfully, by that decision, abortion will replace contraception. It is all very well to say that it allows freedom of choice but, regretfully, the killing of an unborn child ultimately becomes an alternative to contraception.

speech.para: I admire Archbishop Hickey's courage, and I admire the fact that he showed the leadership that he did. I respect Mr Richard Egan for his actions in defending the unborn child.

One of the sad things about our current history is that each year 80,000 immigrants come to Australia in order to stimulate the economy while at the same time 80,000 Australians who would otherwise be born here are killed before birth by being aborted. Euthanasia and abortion are the same in principle; it is just that they are at opposite ends of the life cycle.
